column6: she was; but antebellum glory did not radiate from her as it did from the Major. She possessed a thrifty common sense
column7: and it was she who handled the finances of the family
column8: and met all comers when there were bills to pay. The Major regarded board bills and wash bills as contemptible nuisances. They kept coming in so persistently and so often. Why
column10: could they not be filed and paid in a lump sum at some convenient period—say when the Anecdotes and Reminiscences had been published and paid for? Miss Lydia would calmly go on with her sewing and say
column11: "We'll pay as we go as long as the money lasts
column12: and then perhaps they'll have to lump it."
